Education, in other words, was mobilized as a marketing device for housing policy, which turned schools into selling points while displacing the very children who once relied on them.
In both cases, the house appears not just as a private dwelling but as the centerpiece of a larger system that decides who belongs, who is excluded, and under what terms communities are remade. To encounter the suburban house, then, is to encounter a whole political landscape that makes its rhythms feel natural while rendering exclusion invisible.
If context sets the routines around the house, symbolism reveals what those routines signify. The single-family suburban home does cultural work: it stands for independence, privacy, respectability, and “stability.” However, these meanings are not neutral; they are shaped by design and policy, and they define what it means to succeed in America. Inside, as Dolores Hayden shows, the conventional dwelling conceals unpaid domestic labor by structuring it as private and feminine. Most homes, she writes, are “organized around the same set of spaces: kitchen, dining room, bedrooms, garage or parking area,” and those spaces “require someone to undertake private cooking, cleaning, child care, and usually private transportation if adults and children are to exist within it” (Hayden, 1980, p. 174). Architecture and zoning merge to naturalize this division: the private home becomes both a workspace and a symbol of self-sufficiency, suggesting that independence is achieved through isolation. Hayden’s counter vision of collective kitchens, communal childcare, and housing linked with transit shows how the house’s design encodes a specific ideology of “good” family life, which is not necessarily the only option. Her critique asks who benefits when care is privatized and dependence is hidden.
That same ideology was expanded nationwide through New Deal housing policy, which tied stability, citizenship, and moral worth to suburban homeownership. Programs such as the Home Owners’ Loan Corporation (HOLC) and the FHA intentionally built white wealth. HOLC’s redlining maps classified Black neighborhoods as high-risk, while FHA underwriting manuals explicitly warned that property values would fall if African Americans moved into white areas (Rothstein, 2017). FHA officials even approved suburban developments only when physical barriers, such as highways or walls, separated them from Black neighborhoods (Rothstein, 2017). The result was not just unequal access to housing but the creation of an entire moral economy around it. Homeownership became a symbol of discipline and belonging, while exclusion was reinterpreted as a personal failure. The state-engineered foundation for white middle-class wealth was naturalized as individual merit.
By defining success, happiness, and value around the single-family house and racially controlling access to it, America turned structural inequality into common sense. When those policies were later withdrawn, the wealth gap they created persisted. White families passed down property and equity, while Black families were left out of the system entirely (Rothstein, 2017). Modern suburbs inherited this divide. We now understand many neighborhoods as not white-only but simply wealthy, reframing racism as classism; an easier distinction to accept in a capitalist society because it hides behind the myth of mobility. Yet the physical design of suburban space still enforces exclusion. A Black person walking through a white suburb often appears “out of place,” not just because of prejudice but because the built environment leaves no reason for them to be there. Cul-de-sacs, car dependence, and zoning combine to ensure minimal contact across racial differences, so that even the rare interaction becomes charged with suspicion.
The single-family house, therefore, embodies two symbolic systems simultaneously. Gendered, it makes private labor invisible and dependence seem natural. Racialized, it transforms policy-driven exclusion into a moral story about who belongs. The histories that Hayden, Sinclair, and Rothstein expose, of domestic architecture and racialized expertise, reveal how the world is built into the object: ideology becomes infrastructure. The suburban home does not merely reflect American values; it produces them, teaching generations to mistake privilege for virtue and segregation for order.
In the end, the suburban home reveals what a technology truly is: not a neutral tool, but a system that quietly organizes how we live and think. Its walls contain histories of labor, exclusion, and ideology that have shaped generations, turning design into destiny. To see the house clearly is to see how power hides in the ordinary, and how what feels natural is often the most carefully constructed of all.

Plato took that impulse and tried to build a picture of what justice, knowledge, and reality might look like if you trusted reason above everything else. Their answers were ambitious, sometimes impossibly so, but what stood out was the effort to base their explanations on something other than tradition. That set the tone for the rest of the class: whenever an older framework no longer held together, someone sought to build a new one that made sense for their time.
The medieval material felt like a major shift, even though the underlying questions hadn’t changed much. Thinkers such as Anselm, Aquinas, Bonaventure, and Hildegard were still trying to make sense of the world, but Christianity shaped the entire project in a way the Greeks never addressed. Pascal responded to that uncertainty by leaning on faith, while Bacon tried to design a method that avoided the built-in biases of human thinking. Descartes took a different path altogether, breaking everything down through radical doubt and then rebuilding it around reason and the mind, hoping to secure a foundation for both science and theology. Darwin showed how natural processes could explain what appeared to be design, and Dewey argued that this forced philosophy to rethink ideas such as purpose, certainty, and even what counts as knowledge. The electrification of America began in earnest in 1879 with Thomas Edison's invention of a commercially viable incandescent lamp. At first, electricity was a luxury only available to or even wanted by wealthy households, industries, and cities that wanted street lights, so rural America remained untouched by this technology for the most part. In 1900, less than 5% of industrial power came from electricity; by 1907, only 8% of homes were electrified (Potter, 2023). Early lighting for the general public was primarily limited to gas lights, which had significant limitations. Mainly, gas was dangerous; the lamps required gas to be openly burned in people’s houses, which brought severe health concerns and was incredibly inefficient. In his research on the early electrical grid, Brian Potter, a structural engineer, adds that gas lamps simply had an ugly yellow-green color, and the gas itself would slowly discolor the lamp, eventually requiring a replacement. Arc lights solved some of these problems, but because they were just two nodes passing electricity back and forth, they were dangerous and required so much power that they were only practical for industries and city street lights. Incandescent lighting, a method of heating a filament until it glowed, was considered the solution, but a commercially viable version had not been made (Potter, 2023). In 1879, Edison solved that problem with his incandescent lamp, which brought a safe and practical electric home lighting system and the potential for country-wide illumination if only the country had a reliable power distribution system.
Edison established centralized power stations powered by coal steam engines to address the lack of power distribution. These stations lit thousands of his bulbs within a small radius, making electric light competitive with gas. By 1886, his company had built 58 central stations and 702 smaller stations, eventually serving over 300,000 lamps (Potter, 2023). Despite the success of his stations, there were clear inefficiencies in Edison's model that made them only viable in urban centers, leaving rural America behind in the adoption of electrical power. These inefficiencies highlighted the need for a better power distribution system to allow for more electricity access.
The desire for scalability in power distribution sparked the "War of the Currents." Edison's direct current (DC) system could only transmit power efficiently over short distances because it only allowed for electricity to flow in one direction (Potter, 2023). In contrast, the alternating current (AC) system, championed by Nikola Tesla and George Westinghouse, allowed electricity to flow in both directions and used transformers to adjust the voltage for long-distance transmission (Potter, 2023). This innovation made AC particularly well-suited to serve regions beyond the dense urban center. Tesla’s invention of the AC induction motor and Westinghouse’s investment in AC technology further solidified its advantages, leading to a rapid shift toward AC power by the early 20th century (Potter, 2023).
While the technical capacity to deliver electricity to rural areas existed, utilities prioritized urban centers with higher profit margins. General Electric’s 1921 cartogram, which resized states based on electricity access, vividly illustrates this divide. New York, Massachusetts, and Illinois dominated the map, while rural states were reduced to minuscule proportions. Many historians of early electrification emphasize that AC power was particularly revolutionary because it allowed power plants, especially remote hydroelectric plants, to provide electricity to vast land areas (Potter, 2023; Jeter et al., 2018; Tuttle et al., 2016). This transformation was pivotal for rural electrification, as it made large-scale transmission possible, eventually setting the foundation for even the most isolated communities to gain access to electricity.

	The story of rural electrification is a profound example of how technological progress is not just a matter of engineering but an inherently social, economic, and political negotiation. This process transformed electrification from a top-down imposition into a collaborative effort that reflected the diversity and complexity of rural life.

Like in the 1930s, when power companies focused on cities and wealthier areas, private internet providers today leave rural communities behind, prioritizing profit over access (Cain et al., 2022). Fixing this gap is not just about better technology but about taking a holistic approach, as the REA did. That means combining infrastructure with cultural outreach, involving local communities, and crafting policies that put equality ahead of profits. The REA treated electricity as essential for modern life, and we need to start thinking of broadband similarly. The digital divide is much more than a tech issue; it is a social one, and solving it will take the same kind of innovation, investment, and collaboration that made rural electrification successful.
	At the same time, rural electrification reminds us of the limits of even the most well-meaning government programs. While this paper has touched on how private utilities contributed to the electrification gap, there is still a lot to unpack about their role after the REA was established. Private companies did not just disappear; they remained key players, shaping access and infrastructure in ways that often opposed the REA’s goals. Digging deeper into these dynamics would give a more layered understanding of how public and private forces interacted during rural electrification. It is also worth examining today, especially as we consider the role of private corporations in modern infrastructure, from broadband to renewable energy.
	Ultimately, rural electrification was about far more than lightbulbs and power lines; it was about redefining rural America’s place in the nation. It connected isolated communities to the country's broader social and economic networks, but it did so through negotiation rather than imposition. The REA’s success lay in its ability to foster compromise, allowing rural people to shape electrification as they saw fit while embracing the possibilities of modernization. As we face new challenges, the lessons of rural electrification remind us that progress is not a one-size-fits-all solution. It requires collaboration, adaptability, and a willingness to prioritize the needs of those most affected. The question moving forward is whether we will make those investments again. Rural electrification shows us what is possible when government, technology, and communities work together. However, it also warns us of what happens when progress is driven solely by profit and efficiency; it encourages and entrenches inequality, and opportunities for progressive transformation are lost. If we take the lessons of electrification seriously, we can build a future that is not just more connected but more equitable, one where progress is defined not by who is cheapest or easiest to serve but by who needs it most. What remains to be seen is whether we have the will or political environment to learn from this history and apply it to the challenges of our own time.

Max, thanks for joining me today. Your writings explore themes of identity, like authenticity, the influence of family, and the malleable nature of selfhood after trauma. What sparked your interest in these topics?

Identity has never felt stable to me. Even as a kid, I was aware of being perceived and of performing in ways I didn’t fully understand. As I got older, that instinct turned into a genuine curiosity about how much of the "self" is something you generate versus something that forms around you through family, culture, and circumstance. I don’t think there’s a clean, final answer to any of it, which is part of why it interests me—identity is basically a moving target.
How did backpacking shape that interest?

Backpacking didn’t give me a revelation or anything; it just put me in an environment where a lot of the normal inputs into my identity—school, routines, social expectations—weren’t present. When those disappear, you start noticing what parts of yourself persist and what parts were just reactions to your environment. I wouldn’t call it transformative so much as clarifying. It made me aware that who you are is heavily contingent on context.
You've written about finding solitude within community. Can you expand on that?

I think solitude gets framed as being physically alone, but that doesn't really map onto my experience. Some of the clearest moments of solitude I’ve had were on trips surrounded by people. It’s more about the psychological space you have—being in a group that doesn’t demand anything from you. That kind of solitude is less isolating and more grounding. It makes the boundary between self and community feel more permeable, not less.
How does family fit into your exploration of identity?

Family is basically the first system you’re embedded in, so it shapes you in ways that are hard to separate from your own instincts. A lot of my humor, mannerisms, even how I deal with conflict, trace back to my siblings—sometimes consciously, sometimes not. What interests me is how those influences become invisible over time, and how much of what we call a 'personality' is just accumulated imitation plus whatever conditions we grew up in.
You've engaged a lot with determinism—the idea that our lives are shaped by forces beyond our control. How has that affected your understanding of yourself and the world?

Determinism is the scaffolding for how I think about identity. I don’t believe in free will in any deep sense, so I don’t think the self is something you author from scratch. It’s more like a process shaped by biology, experience, and whatever systems you’re embedded in. That doesn’t make life meaningless—it just means the meaning we experience is something the brain generates, not something metaphysically grounded. Paradoxically, that view makes me more empathetic. If no one controls their wants or circumstances, judgment stops feeling like a useful category.
What draws you to subjects like literature, philosophy, and history?

They’re all different ways of interrogating how humans construct meaning. Literature shows how people make sense of themselves; philosophy tests the assumptions behind those interpretations; history reveals how material conditions shape entire worldviews. None of them give definitive answers, but together they let you see the same problem from multiple angles.
You're often drawn to challenging themes like colonialism or mental illness. Why those topics?

Because they expose the gap between how societies narrate themselves and how they actually function. Colonialism, mental illness, any kind of systemic harm—those topics force you to confront the limits of individual agency and the power of structures. They make it obvious that people don’t act in a vacuum, which aligns with how I already think about determinism and identity.
In your analysis of 'Purple Hibiscus', you discuss the cycle of abuse perpetuated by wealth and power. What did you take away from that?

What interested me wasn’t just the abuse itself but how the family structure normalizes it. Eugene’s power—social, financial, moral—creates an environment where the rest of the family internalizes his worldview. It shows how easily authority gets mistaken for virtue, and how systems of belief can trap people in harm even when the individual causing it is seen as admirable from the outside.
Your essay on 'Slaughterhouse-Five' examines identity shifts across time. What resonated with you in that idea?

Billy Pilgrim’s fractured relationship with time is an exaggerated version of something real: the fact that different versions of ourselves coexist. The self isn’t a single continuous entity—it’s more like snapshots we stitch together after the fact. That idea aligns with my broader sense that identity is constructed, unstable, and shaped by forces we don’t control.
You've written about how language shapes perception, like in 'Please Look After Mom'. Can you elaborate?

Second-person narration forces the reader into the role of the character, blurring the boundary between observer and participant. It exposes how easily language can restructure your sense of responsibility or guilt. It’s a good example of how form—not just content—shapes meaning and emotional impact.

What stuck wasn’t just coding—it was the idea that you can build a system and watch behavior emerge that you didn’t explicitly design. CS is one of the few fields where you can model parts of the real world without pretending you have perfect information or perfect theories. That’s what keeps me interested.

Does this interactive approach to systems influence other areas of your life or studies?

Explaining ideas to other people helps too—it forces you to see where the logic collapses. That pattern carries over into CS, philosophy, pretty much everything.
How has this hands-on learning style shaped your curiosity?

It keeps me from feeling intimidated by things that look complex. Once you start interacting with a system directly, it usually stops being mysterious. That doesn’t mean you fully understand it, but it shifts the problem from ‘this is impossible’ to ‘this is complicated but tractable.’
What current project or subject are you diving into with this approach?

Lately it’s been more on the modeling side—agent-based systems, transformers for sequential data, simulation work, stuff like that. At the same time, CS classes are introducing new paradigms, which forces me to rethink what I thought I understood. I’m also still interested in consciousness, but that’s more of a philosophical side project than something I’m actively coding.
Are there any concepts or philosophical models of consciousness that have influenced your thinking?

Damasio’s framework is interesting—not because I agree with all of it, but because it tries to bridge the gap between low-level biological processes and the subjective experience of being a self. It’s useful as a model of how the feeling of agency might arise, even if the model doesn’t solve the underlying metaphysics.

How do your determinist views interact with theories like Damasio’s?

I treat theories like his as attempts to explain why consciousness feels the way it does, not as explanations of actual freedom. Most frameworks sneak free will back in through the language they use. Determinism, for me, is the background assumption—whatever model you’re evaluating still has to be compatible with the idea that everything is caused.
How would you reconcile determinism with Damasio’s account?

I think his account can describe the mechanisms generating the illusion of agency. There’s no contradiction there unless you insist the feeling of choice has to map onto metaphysical choice. I don’t see any reason it needs to.
How does your belief in determinism influence your decision-making or problem-solving?

In practice, I still feel like I’m making choices because that’s how consciousness presents itself. But determinism changes how I interpret those choices. I see them as outcomes of prior causes rather than expressions of a free self. It doesn’t change what I do moment to moment; it changes how I think about responsibility and behavior.
How does your belief in determinism affect your future in computer science?

It pushes me toward modeling. If you believe behavior is the result of interacting causes, then building systems that approximate that structure feels meaningful. It also removes the need to account for some undefined ‘free will variable’ when you’re trying to simulate anything involving humans. Determinism simplifies things, in a way.
How does determinism help you think about modeling real-world systems?

It sets a constraint: everything that happens has a cause, even if you can’t identify it. That constraint makes modeling easier because you’re not trying to simulate exceptions. You’re just trying to approximate the mechanisms. The hard part is the complexity, not the philosophy.
What’s your long-term goal when it comes to modeling systems?

I’d like to model how people think and act, not in a sci-fi sense but in a systemic one—what factors interact to produce behavior, and how those interactions scale. I’m more interested in what those models imply about society than in trying to recreate a person perfectly.
Do you think your worldview is built on determinism?

Yeah, pretty much. It shapes how I understand morality, identity, politics—everything. But I don’t walk around consciously thinking about determinism. The illusion of choice is too strong. So my worldview is deterministic, but my day-to-day experience is still that I’m choosing things.
Do you believe you are a human, or is it possible you’re a simulation?

I operate with the assumption that I’m human because that’s what my experience presents to me. Could that be wrong? Sure, but there’s no way to meaningfully evaluate it. I do make a distinction between being a person and being a human—a computer could theoretically be a person if it had consciousness, but it still wouldn’t be human in the biological sense. I don’t spend much time on simulation speculation because it doesn’t change anything about how I live.

Music matters a lot to me, mostly because it lets people express ideas and emotions in a way that isn’t literal but still precise. I gravitate toward albums that build a little world and reward close listening. If I made music, it would probably be long, nonlinear, and metaphor-heavy—more about the feeling behind an idea than the idea itself. Basically the kind of music I already listen to.
What do you want to study in college?

I’m studying Computer Science and STS with an AI concentration. CS gives me the tools to model systems, and STS forces me to think about those systems in their actual social and historical context. The combination makes the most sense for the kinds of questions I care about.
